The value of sharing information!

elements.value: Who created this platform and why?

The IUCN Center for Mediterranean Cooperation has designed and structured this collaborative storytelling and knowledge sharing platform to increase the visibility of information and data generated in collaboration with the peer review community in the region in recent years.
What kind of information can I find in this platform?

You will find a combination of authoritative maps with narrative text, images, and multimedia content based on publications and reports edited by IUCN-Med in collaboration with other key stakeholders in the region. We are also accepting relevant examples from other regional stakeholders for publication so that this platform becomes a dynamic collaboration space.
All maps are available for download and may be harvested by other geoportals as long as the source is mentioned.
How can I use this platform?
In addition to reviewing data and downloading/sharing it, this platform is open to other organizations that wish to share geo-reference information on Mediterranean biodiversity conservation.
You can submit a story by sharing a map, text and uploading images, video, or web links.
Contact us for more details.

cover.name: Cover
cover.title: Do you know where the most beautiful Mediterranean diving secrets are?
cover.subtitle: Mediterranean corals

elements.value: Coralligenous habitats are often called 'coral gardens or forests'. These colourful landscapes can be found growing on a variety of locations and at depths ranging from 20 to 200 meters.

They are however known to be decreasing in quality and quantity, despite not counting with exhaustive information. They are threatened by pollution and various fishing techniques and gears that get entangled in the corals.
The designation of <b>Marine Protected Areas<b/> and specific measures like the ban of trawling should help protect these submarine gardens.
Figures
The coralligenous is considered as the second benthic ecosystem in the Mediterranean and host 1700 species, among them 1300 algae, 1200 invertebrate species, and more than hundred fish species.
The decline in habitat extent and quality make them to be classified as Near Threatened for Europe.

An important feature of this habitat to be considered also is that in the Mediterranean, up to 48% of the algae species living in them are endemics, according to the European Red List of Habitats, which covers information in the EU28, plus Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the Balkan countries and their neighbouring seas.

credit.footer: European Red List of Habitats, EIONET

elements.value: Conservation curiosities
Coralline reefs are considered hotspots of biodiversity and are extremely popular among divers due to their complex structure, noticeable biological wealth and high aesthetic value.

Coralligenous bioconcretions or coralline reefs are mainly produced by the accumulation of calcareous encrusting algae growing and shaping these structures where a rich associated fauna flourish in dim light conditions.

Coralline reefs with species like Paramuricea clavata, Eunicella verrucosa and Astroides calycularis, and of course the precious Red Coral (Corallium rubrum), are Mediterranean treasures that form part of our heritage.

Indeed, it is worth considering that that some of these ecosystems are estimated to take several thousand years to be built, as in the case of the corbels of Lithophylum algae, which constitute real natural monuments.

info.title: Infralittoral biogenic habitats in the Mediterranean - corralligenous bioconcretions

elements.value: Coralligenous habitats are reported to occur primarily in the northern part of the Mediterranean basin, with few records from the eastern or southern basin. The availability of data and expertise meant that only countries on the northern shores of the Mediterranean together with Turkey, Malta and Cyprus were included in the Mediterranean Sea assessments.
There is a clear lack of data and knowledge for coralligenous habitats in the south and east of the Mediterranean.
In March 2008, the countries in the Barcelona Convention adopted an Action Plan to protect these important habitats.

The benign climate, gastronomic variety and various cultures inhabiting the area attract millions of visitors each year to the Mediterranean shores. Although the overall trend is unknown, we already know that shallow water coralligenous habitats are known to be decreasing in quality. It is therefore critical to protect and promote a healthy marine environment for them to maintain the Mediterranean as we know it today.

To reverse this trend towards disappearance, we need to join forces from several sectors in a concerted effort to protect their locations against pollution, trawling and fishing, or unsupervised anchoring among others.
The designation of Marine Protected Areas and fisheries reserves are needed conservation of this habitat.
Hence that measures such as further data collection and monitoring, new regulations and the protection of important areas are being promoted.
Because our marine gardens and forests take a long time to grow, but very little to be destroyed…

In fact, one of the most beautiful habitats in the Mediterranean are coralligenous gardens, where trees are replaced by soft corals (gorgonians) and flowers give way to calcareous red algae and animals such as sponges and bryozoans. These wondrous places support a high biodiversity, and steps are now being taken to better protect them

Oceana comments on the Action Plan for the conservation of the Coralligenous and other calcareous bio-concretions in the Mediterranean Sea adopted by the Mediterranea states at the Cop18 Barcelona Convention.

cover.name: Cover
cover.title: The case of the disappearing butteflies
cover.subtitle: Mediterranean Butterflies

elements.value: Since ancient times, people have recognized the wide range of environmental benefits provided by a thriving butterfly population. In fact, visual representations honoring butterflies from 3,500 years ago can be  seen in Ancient Egyptian frescoes.

In addition to their role as pollinators and food sources for other species, some butterflies have even developed their own strategies to deter predators and parasites, find mates, or overcome their host plant´s chemical defenses.

However during the last 50 years massive changes in human behaviors have begun to change life for butterflies in the Mediterranean region, including unsustainable agricultural practices, urbanization and increased tourism visitation and infrastructure. These changes are leading to the disappearance of some of the world´s most colourful, unique, and important creatures.
A recent IUCN report revealed that 15% of the Mediterranean´s endemic butterflies are currently threatened with extinction.

credit.footer: Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.

elements.value: 98 species of butterflies are endemic to the Mediterranean -- that is, they occur only in the region. The majority of these endemic species are concentrated in North Africa.
Information is still needed on the geographic distribution of butterflies and the size and  reproductive trends of their populations, mostly for species south and east of the Mediterranean.

Butterflies are one of the most iconic and popular insects for many people and have fascinating life-cycles that are used in many countries to teach children about the natural world. However, in many parts of Mediterranean Europe butterflies are in decline because of changes in the agricultural system, and could be even lost if action is not taken urgently.
elements.credit: Dr Chris van Swaay, chair of Butterfly Conservation Europe

elements.value: Conservation curiosities: Why do butterflies have scaly wings ?
Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for 'scales' and ptera means 'wings'. Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in the natural history of butterflies. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal or camouflage for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility, in order to prevent a predator from attacking.
Amazing animals!

• Many butterflies have taste receptors on their feet. and they can see red, green, and yellow.
  • Antarctica is the only continent on which no Lepidoptera have been found.
  • Butterflies are unable to fly if their body temperature drops below 30ºC

info.title: Butterfly species richness in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: Altogether 463 butterfly species have been recorded in the Mediterranean, and they are not equally distributed across the region. This map highlights areas with high concentrations of butterfly species diversity.

The highest level of species richness is found in mountainous areas where the diversity of microclimates favors many species adapted to different microhabitats, e.g. in southern France, the higher parts of northern Greece as well as southern Turkey.

info.title: Distribution of threatened butterflies in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: There are 19 threatened butterflies in the Mediterranean region, including 15 endemic species. This means nearly 5% of all butterfly species are threatened in the Mediterranean region, 2% are considered Near Threatened, and more than 6 % are Data Deficient according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
In the Mediterranean, butterflies are slightly less threatened than in Europe (8%), probably because of the higher area of remaining natural and semi-natural habitats throughout the region.

info.title: Species richness of endemic butterflies in the Mediterranean region

elements.value: Altogether there are 98 endemic butterfly species in the Mediterranean region, and the majority are concentrated in the north of Africa, especially in the Rif Mountains, the High and Middle Atlas Mountains in Morocco, and the Aurès Mountains in Algeria.
There are also important zones with endemism in the southeast of Spain (Sierra Nevada and Sierra of Baza), on the islands of Corsica and Sardinia, in southern Turkey and in Lebanon.
The group of experts working in collaboration with the IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation recommend appropriate habitat management to improve the conservation status of these valuable species.
The experts also propose urgent conservation measures to safeguard this natural capital in the region by:

• Fully implementing national and international legislation
  • Developing and implementing habitat action plans in areas where butterflies are threatened
  • Prioritizing field work and data collection for Data Deficient butterflies.

cover.title: Is the Mediterranean eating its sharks?
cover.subtitle: Mediterranean Butterflies

elements.value: Butterflies provide a wide range of environmental benefits. In addition to their role as pollinators and food for others, some have even developed their own ways to deter predators and parasites, find a mate, or overcome the chemical defences of their host plant. Each of these butterfly chemicals has a potential value and could be exploited economically. Powerful antibiotics for example have been found in the Meadow Brown (Maniola jurtina), one common and widespread species.

The last 50 years have however seen a massive change in agricultural practices across the Mediterranean, with a loss of wildlife-rich habitats by increasing urbanization and tourism infrastructure. The growing chronic water shortages are also having a major socio-economic impact on large parts of the region, as many small-scale farmers feel forced to abandon their land to search for jobs elsewhere. Land abandonment leads to former grassland getting overgrown with shrubs, turning into secondary forests and therefore reducing suitable habitats for many butterfly species. Overgrazing can reduce the availability of nutritious plants and refuge for larvae too. These changes are leading to the disappearance of some of these colourful and unique creatures.
Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for  "scales" and ptera means "wings". Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in their natural history. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal, camouflage, for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility to prevent a predator from preying on it.
Scales are also present on the thorax and other parts of the butterfly to  contribute to maintaining the high body temperatures required during flight.

elements.value: The IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation is evaluating the state of conservation of a selection of taxonomic groups in the Mediterranean region. There are 463 butterflies native to the Mediterranean and the assessment recently published by IUCN reveals that 19 butterfly species are threatened with extinction, among which 15 endemic species.

credit.footer: Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.

elements.value: There is still an information gap on the geographic distribution of butterflies, the size and the reproduction trends of their populations, mostly for species south and east of the Mediterranean. Beyond further data collection and monitoring, a review of legislation affecting their protection and action plans for particular species and habitats are the main recommendations from experts to encourage the preservation of these winged creatures in the Mediterranean landscape.

elements.value: Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for  "scales" and ptera means "wings". Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in their natural history. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal, camouflage, for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility to prevent a predator from preying on it.
Scales are also present on the thorax and other parts of the butterfly to  contribute to maintaining the high body temperatures required during flight.
Butterflies are considered good indicators for the state of the environment and due to their short cycle, narrow niches and relatively low mobility, they are very sensitive to land-use changes.

Despite the percentage of threatened butterflies being lower than in other groups in the region, there is a lack of information on the distribution, population size and trends for several species, which could mean an increased number of threatened species. Agricultural intensification, overgrazing and land abandonment are a threat to Mediterranean butterfly diversity.

At present there are 22 countries where butterflies are monitored. However, most of them are not situated in the Mediterranean region, with the exception of Spain and France. There is therefore a need to increase data collection and monitoring on the southern and eastern shores of the Mediterranean, where many endemic species inhabit, as a first step to ensure their protection through better legislation and concrete action plans.

Butterflies have been for a long time a symbol for transformation and evolution. One also talks about the "butterfly effect" when small causes can have large effects.  Indeed, despite their small size, butterflies are key pieces in the Mediterranean landscape. They participate in the essential ecosystems functioning as pollinators and as prey for other species during their different life cycles. Aesthetic and cultural values are also associated to their presence in the region, adding colour and beauty to Mediterranean mountains, grasslands and landscapes.
Agricultural intensification, overgrazing and land abandonment are a threat to Mediterranean butterfly diversity. Forest fires and climate change are also risks to their survival.

Conservation actions necessary for their protection are the review of national and international legislation to include threatened species, and the device of species/habitat action plans where most needed. Field work and data monitoring for Data Deficient species, with strong regional cooperation as the basis, are also needed all along the Mediterranean.

The highest diversity of butterflies is found in mountainous areas in southern Turkey, northern Greece and southern France.

79% of threatened species are endemic. Such is the case of  the Karpathos Grayling (Hipparchia christenseni) which is found on rocky slopes covered with open scrub and in clearings in coniferous woods, where the butterflies often rest on the trunks of trees. This species occurs only on the Greek island of Karpathos.
